awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is a Molybdenum Disulfide Oil Water Separator (MDSOS) which, resembling a sponge, is a porous material designed to absorb oil while simultaneously repelling water due to its superhydrophobic properties. Unlike common methods of oil treatment/removal, such as burning and the use of dispersants, the use of the Molybdenum Disulfide sponges mitigates the environmental effects of these common methods.  The implementation of the system can be low-cost and have high durability in varying aquatic conditions. The current laboratory prototype is suitable for small-scale contaminations with markets relevant to those that transport or handle oil in aquatic regions, such as boat owners and marinas. The design of MDSOS permits adjustability in fabrication specific to the oil of desired absorption, allowing compatibility with any type of oil.  MDSOS could potentially be part of remediation efforts for large-scale oil spills.

This I-Corps project further develops a platform of superhydrophobic and superoleophilic molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) sponge technology to improve oil-water separation as well as other industrial applications. The platform has unique combination of material properties and process advantages. This merit comes from the combined attributes of; (1) low materials cost and weight due to their extremely small thickness (ultimately down to a single layer of atoms) and (2) their facile chemical synthesis which does not require cost-demanding equipment/process. Thus, the technology platform can potentially be applied to perform environmental bioremediation, oil spill cleaning, and oily wastewater treatment.  The project primarily enables the customer discovery  to validate potential customer segments and product-market fit.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES

por.por_cntn:
The proposed technology goes by the name Molybdenum Disulfide Oil Water Separator or MDSOS. The core technology is a superhydrophobic and superoleophilic molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) based sponge and its application in adsorption of oil and organic solvent materials in oil-water environments. The sponges are fabricated by combining nanostructured MoS2 flakes and an elastomeric polymer sponge with controlled geometries. The MoS2 sponge?s high porosity allows for efficient absorption of oil while its superhydrophobicity simultaneously repels water. This I-Corps project is based on superhydrophobic and superoleophilic molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) sponge technology and aims to advance technological development to improve oil-water separation as well as industrial applications to deliver results effectively. 2D MoS2 renders great economic feasibility due to their unique material properties and process advantages. This merit comes from the combined attributes of; (1) their lowest possible materials cost and weight due to their extremely small thickness ? ultimately, down to a single layer of atoms and (2) their facile chemical synthesis which does not require cost-demanding equipment/process, resulting in green and sustainable results. Thus, the MDSOS can aid oil processing/related industries which are under regulations for their oil discharge or oil treatment industries to perform environmental bioremediation, oil spill cleanings, and oily wastewater treatment. The project primarily seeks to conduct additional customer discovery needed to validate our customer segments and product/market fit. To that end, our innovation would be a cost-effective sustainable option for better oil removal/treatment for users.

 

The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is a Molybdenum Disulfide Oil Water Separator or MDSOS which, resembling a sponge, is a porous material designed to absorb oil while simultaneously repelling water due to its superhydrophobic properties. Unlike common methods of oil treatment/removal, such as burning and the use of dispersants, the use of the MoS2 sponges mitigates secondhand pollution towards the environment and people. Although the main objective of this technology is to protect and maintain aquatic regions for the health of the environment and the use of people, this design also incorporates economic prosperity. Overall implementation is extremely low-cost with high durability in varying aquatic conditions. The current laboratory prototype is suitable for small-scale contaminations with markets relevant to those that transport or handle oil in aquatic regions, such as boat owners and marinas. The design of MDSOS permits adjustability in fabrication specific to the oil of desired absorption, allowing compatibility with any type of oil. With ongoing technological research and development, MDSOS exhibits potential as part of remediation efforts put forth for large-scale oil spills. 


Last Modified: 09/18/2021
Modified by: Woo Hyoung Lee

The MoS2 sponge?s high porosity allows for efficient absorption of oil while its superhydrophobicity simultaneously repels water. This I-Corps project is based on superhydrophobic and superoleophilic molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) sponge technology and aims to advance technological development to improve oil-water separation as well as industrial applications to deliver results effectively. 2D MoS2 renders great economic feasibility due to their unique material properties and process advantages. Unlike common methods of oil treatment/removal, such as burning and the use of dispersants, the use of the MoS2 sponges mitigates secondhand pollution towards the environment and people.
